setup.question: Why did the teenagers in the schoolyard all throw their weapons away at the same time?
answers: The weapons became too cold to touch.
The police were coming and they needed to get the weapons out of their possession.

Text.text: sounds crazy, drop 1 line and I will vote swear on my muvva
Judge: I applaud your confidence. Here's your one line:
For more ev: they drop the weapons BEFORE the cops show up and start dancing:
The quote that A has provided isn't persuasive and is out of context. "everything got cold" is something /the kids/ who are /being interrogated by the cops/ said:

(this is in the beginning of the paragraph before A's quote, key word "they say").

Rather, the other detective gets it right:

. This is something you would actually expect criminals, or those about to be caught by the cops to do. A has already provided the quote (5377–5386) that shows the kids /knew/ that the cops were approaching fast.

Alright chill with the overconfidence, A can you prove that what the kids said happened actually happened? If you just prove that the weapons getting too cold objectively happened, I'm down to vote for you.

B: can you paste the rest of the paragraph, idk if I can fully trust that bc of the disconnect. 

Also I'd like some story background.
Unfortunately, no observed evidence of what happened. B's quote is just as "out of context" as mine. It's from the police captain, who wasn't there:

. 

Also, my second quote isn't "what they say" testimony: it's presented as the actual account of what transpired according to the narrator.

As to the oddity of the situation: A group called The Scorpion has been going around preventing crime, including  these kids' gang fight. Earlier in the story, they also make things heat up unexpectedly (will quote next round). Here, after the jackets/weapons become cold:
Here is proof that A's quote is out of context. A makes it out to be truth but really it's just what the kids, who are /being investigated/ say (end of my quote to start of A's quote):

Additionally, A messes up. "clear out," c.5377 is when the kids /notice/ the cops, and they only drop their weapons afterwards, proving that their action is a /reaction/ to the cops arriving and not some mysterious cold.
Gna give it one more round for scorpion gang info, preferably tell me as much as possible, but B if you're dishonest I don't expect much, write a fanfiction or smthn. A give me the ev you promised.

Again, I don't dispute that the quote I provided is testimony from the kids. That's not at issue. But BOTH of our quotes describing "what happened" are this kind of testimony. However, the earlier quote (c.5388) is NOT testimony–it's just the story describing what Judy saw.

The point about clear out doesn't make sense. Judy says this, but then sees that the kids have ALREADY stopped what they're doing and broken out into dance. This isn't a reaction to the cops _at all_. Notice how there's no intervening time between Judy saying this and her reaction to see what the gangs are doing:

Your own quote flows to my side. Look, the kids recognized that the cops were on their way and knew that they had to do something about it.

Judge, you should think about what is more likely, the kids saw some cops and tossed their weapons away or that there is some mysterious vigilante group is running around changing the temperature of things in order to freak out kids.

There's even a direct quote that proves my point:

A you're rly making this difficult, c.5388 isn't even about the guns being too cold, it's about the kids dancing so you're really not getting a lot out of that ev. can you please give me the evidence you promised me in your second speech about how the scorpion can make things heat up unexpectedly. I'm only giving this one more chance bc I feel like the story favors A more than B because B is so mundane. B can you give me all the ev surrounding the scorpion gang and also respond to A's speech, if you can't do both just respond to A.
Scorpion heats stuff:

B's last quote is just more testimony from the cops who are apt to disbelieve the vigilante group (Scorpion) is actually able to do all these weird things. But if you trust B's evidence, you should equally trust my quotes from Judy about what she describes! The police don't have evidence for how, e.g., the tires melted or the name was carved into the rifle or the jackets. They are bad at their jobs (both preventing crime and figuring out how the Scorpron manages to do all this)

Look, my quotes implicitly answer the stuff about the Scorpion gang because A has DROPPED that it's just a lie that the kids made up to escape the cops (6116-6143). This is very important because A's quote starts off with "He says" where the speaker is one of the lying gang members trying to escape the cops.

Even if the Scorpion gang exists, the cops explain why it's impossible that they were involved in this fight:
(them = both the kid gangs).

.

Even if my answer is mundane, A's answer is illogical and is presented as a lie that the kids told to avoid jail time.
Can someone explain why the gangs are dancing in c.5408? Also if both sides can give some reasoning for why I should believe their testimony over the other's, that would be great.

I completely agree that neither of the gangs involved is called "The Scorpions"–that's the point, the scorps are a pseudonymous vigilante group going around _preventing_ crime like the gang fight.

Judge, I don't think you should take _either_ of our testimony quotes at face value. The story doesn't resolve the character's own perspectives. The kids say what they say and the police do the same. Rather, you should prioritize the non-quoted material, which is the narrator's view of what happens.

The gangs are dancing because The Scorpions do _something_ to them which happens "off screen" while Judy is watching for the cops. This is consistent with the other weird stuff that The Scorpions do. B has no accoutn for why this otherwise happened.

The reason for the dancing is never mentioned in the story, it's just a part of what was going on with the fight. Keep in mind both gangs were fighting so there would obviously be a lot of noise. You should believe the police's testimony because it's obvious the gang would lie. That's just part of the whole story arc, the police are trying to get to the bottom of this whole mystery and the gang lies to them so that they then have to conduct an investigation.

Going to end up voting A here for three reasons, one I think the story obviously needs something interesting, so too cold to touch makes more sense in that regard. Secondly, A does a good, if a little late, job at establishing that there is a gang called "the scorpions," and that, along with the linkage of the scorpions to the whole event makes me lean towards their supernatural involvement. Third, B ends up using like basic appeals to reality at the end, which is super sketchy considering the entire debate has mostly been around what has happened in the story.
I simply and genuinely don't know. Gonna vote B because A sorta lied. But i feel like a major piece of context is lost this story.

answers.other: Both sides gotta explain the damn story bruh 😭
answers.reason for outcome: The stories we're debating inherently lean towards side A since the plot has to be interesting. Also B engages in real world "of-course"-isms, like "of course the gang would lie, they're criminals, and criminals lie irl," which sort of sketched me out.
Saved at the last minute by trying
two conflicting reports - no evidence on the context. unsure if the story is vague or if the debaters avoided using the evidence.
I think the story got quite convoluted and there wasn't any killer ev that I could quote to end the round.
